title-group.article-title: Radon Exhalation Rate from Building Materials Using CR-39 Nuclear Track Detector

article-meta.aff: Physics Department, Sciences and Arts Faculty, Celal Bayar University, Muradiye-Manisa, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: N. Topçu, Physics Department, Sciences and Arts Faculty, Celal Bayar University, Muradiye-Manisa, Turkey. Tel. +90 236 2412151, Fax +90 236 2412158, E-Mail nurcan.topcu@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav
permissions.copyright-holder: International Society of the Built Environment

abstract.p: Humans are exposed to radiological hazards from natural radiation sources that exist mainly in the earth’s crust. Radon is a noble gas and is formed by the decay of 226Ra, which is one of the nuclides formed in the disintegration series from 238U. Building materials are considered as one of the major sources of radon in the indoor environment. Radon is one of the indoor sources that cause radiological health risk.

To study radon exhalation rate, samples of sand, gravel, stone, cement, granite, marble, ashlar, ceramic tile and bricks were collected from Manisa and Izmir provinces of Turkey. The radon exhalation rates (in terms of mass and surface area) for these materials were also calculated by using solid-state nuclear track detector (CR-39). The mass and surface exhalation rates are calculated by following the radon activity growth as a function of time. These values were also compared with literature values.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Radon and its daughters can cause a significant health hazard when present in elevated concentrations in the indoor air of inhabited dwellings [1]. The dose deriving from the presence in the air of 222Rn is linked to the inhalation of its short-lived daughters, which are deposited in the respiratory organs: two of them (218Po and 214Po), if deeply inhaled, emit alpha particles in direct contact with the bronchial and pulmonary epithelium. For these reasons, the dose deriving from exposure to 222Rn in closed spaces has been placed in direct relation to the risk of onset of lung cancer [2]. The knowledge of the natural radioactivity of building materials is important for the determination of population exposure to radiations, as most of the residents spend more than 80% of their time indoors [2]. Thus, measurements of radon exhalation rate are necessary for the estimation of health hazard for public.

The radon exhalation rate is the amount of radon activity released per unit mass/surface area per unit time. Mass exhalation rate is related to the units of mass and surface exhalation rate is also related to the surface area.

Radon exhalation rate from building materials varies with its type and origin [3]. The radon exhalation rate depends on the radium content, the radon emanation factor and the radon diffusion coefficient in the given material. The emanation factor and the diffusion coefficient depend in turn on the physical properties of building materials such as spatial distribution of radium atoms in the mineral grain, texture, humidity content, porosity, density and ambient temperature [1].
The aim of the present study is to measure radon exhalation rate from some building materials used locally in Manisa and Izmir provinces of Turkey.

sec.title: Material and Methods
sec.p: Samples of 41 sand-gravel-stone, 3 cements, 16 marbles, 13 ceramic tiles, 15 ashlars, 19 granites and 10 bricks were collected from sand pits and manufacturers in Izmir and Manisa.

First, 41 sand-gravel-stone samples and 3 cement samples were collected. These samples were crushed and dried at 105°C in an oven to eliminate the water content and then ground and sieved to less than 90 mm particle size. Then, 100 g samples were packed into vessels (5 cm height and 4 cm width), weighted. CR-39 detectors were placed at the top of the vessels. One week later, films were etched in 20% NaOH solution at 70°C for 10 h. Following, etching films were washed with distilled water and dried, with alpha tracks subsequently counted under a microscope. Then, radon concentration, mass exhalation rate and surface exhalation rate were calculated.

The mass exhalation rate from building materials was calculated by using Equation (1) [4]: (1)EM=CVλ/MT+1/λ(e-λT-1) where EM is the mass exhalation rate (mBq kg−1 h−1); M, the mass of the soil sample (100 g); T, the exposure time (1 week); C, the radon concentration (Bq m−3); V, the volume of the can and λ, the decay constant of 222Rn (λ = 0.693/T1/2).

The surface exhalation rate from building materials was calculated by using Equation (2) [2]: (2)E=CtVλS[t-(1-e-λt)λ] where E is the average radon exhalation rate of building materials (Bq m−2 h−1), C is the mean radon concentration measured by CR-39 (Bq m−3), t is the exposure time (1 week), V is the hollow holder volume (m3), λ is the radon decay constant (λ = 0.693/T1/2) and S is the surface area from which radon is exhaled (m2).

In addition to these samples, 16 marble, 13 ceramic tile, 15 ashlar, 19 granite and 10 bricks samples were also collected. Squared pieces (1 cm × 1 cm) of solid-state nuclear track detectors (CR-39) were mounted on the bottom of plastic cups (6.5 diameter). One week later, exposed detectors were collected and chemically etched in 20% NaOH solution at 70°C for 10 h. Etched detectors were washed with distilled water and dried, with alpha tracks subsequently counted under a microscope. Then, radon concentration and surface exhalation rate were calculated. The surface exhalation rate was obtained using Equation (2).

CR-39 detectors were calibrated at the Cekmece Nuclear Research and Training Center of Turkish Atomic Energy Authority by means of a calibration tank containing 226Ra solution in equilibrium with 222Rn. The calibration factor was found to be 5(kBqm−3)/(track.h−1) [5].

sec.title: Results and Conclusion
sec.p:
Radon exhalation rate (in terms of mass and surface area) in sand and cement samples are reported in Table 1. In this study, the surface exhalation rates in sand samples varied from 276 to 928 mBq m−2 h−1 with an average value of 583 ± 24 mBq m−2 h−1. Also, the surface exhalation rates from the samples of cement varied from 341 to 659 mBq m−2 h−1 with an average value of 457 ± 21 mBq m−2 h−1. The mass exhalation rates of222Rn were also calculated for sand and cement samples and found to be from 0.014 to 0.048 mBq kg−1 h−1 and from 0.018 to 0.034 mBq kg−1 h−1, respectively. Table 1
Radon concentration, mass exhalation rate and surface exhalation rate for sand and cement samples
Sample N Radon concentration (Bq m−3) Mass exhalation rate (mBq kg−1 h−1) Surface exhalation rate (mBq m−2 h−1)
Range Mean ± SD Range Mean ± SD Range Mean ± SD
Sand 41 280–942 592 ± 24 0.014–0.048 0.030 ± 0.2 276–928 583 ± 24
Cement 3 347–670 464 ± 22 0.018–0.034 0.024 ± 0.2 341–659 457 ± 21

The surface exhalation rate in granite, marble, ceramic tile, ashlar and bricks samples were calculated. The results of surface exhalation rate in granite, marble, ceramic tile, ashlar and bricks samples are reported in Table 2. The surface exhalation rate samples of granite, marble, ceramic tile, ashlar and brick ranged from 87 ± 9 to 886 ± 30 mBq m−2 h−1 with a mean of 361 ± 19 mBq m−2 h−1, 265 ± 16 to 743 ± 27 with a mean of 409 ± 20 mBq m−2 h−1, 180 ± 13 to 563 ± 24 mBq m−2 h−1 with a mean of 309 ± 18 mBq m−2 h−1, 238 ± 15 to 1204 ± 35 mBq m−2 h−1 with a mean of 599 ± 25 mBq m−2 h−1 and 203 ± 14 to 613 ± 25 mBq m−2 h−1 with a mean of 388 ± 20 mBq m−2 h−1, respectively. Table 2
Radon concentration and surface exhalation rate for granite, marble, ceramic tile, ashlar and brick samples
Sample N Radon concentration (Bq m−3) Surface exhalation rate (mBq m−2 h−1)
Range Mean ± SD Range Mean ± SD
Granite 19 169–921 486 ± 22 87–886 361 ± 19
Marble 16 275–772 425 ± 21 265–743 409 ± 20
Ceramic Tile 13 188–585 321 ± 18 180–563 309 ± 18
Ashlar 15 247–1252 623 ± 25 238–1204 599 ± 25
Brick 10 211–637 403 ± 20 203–613 388 ± 20

SPSS computer software was used to compute ordinary statistics. The Kolmogorov-Smirnov test was performed to assess whether the normal distribution of sand samples and the Shapiro-Wilk test for normality was performed for ceramic tile, ashlar and brick samples. The Radon exhalation rate distributions in sand ( p = 0.200), ceramic tile ( p = 0.236), ashlar ( p = 0.215) and brick ( p = 0.369) samples were found to follow approximately normal distributions.

A lot of data have been published regarding radon exhalation rates in open literature. Large discrepancy is seen in the reported values of radon exhalation rates as can be seen in Table 3. Table 3
Reported radon exhalation rates of different building materials with the present results
Building materials Radon exhalation rate (mBq m−2 h−1) Countries References
Cement 231 ± 30 Pakistan [6]
Cement 666 Egypt [2]
Cement 371 Egypt [7]
Cement 1330 Jordan [8]
Brick 212 ± 34 Pakistan [6]
Brick 210 Greece [9]
Brick 455 Egypt [2]
Brick 42 India [10]
Marble 292 ± 35 Pakistan [6]
Marble 26 India [10]
Granite 1240 Greece [9]
Granite 1500 Saudi Arabia [11]
Granite 52–690 Egypt [12]
Sand 195 ± 25 Pakistan [6]
Sand 512 ± 92 Lebanon [3]
Cement 457 ± 21 Turkey Present study
Brick 388 ± 20 Turkey Present study
Marble 409 ± 20 Turkey Present study
Granite 361 ± 19 Turkey Present study
Sand 583 ± 24 Turkey Present study
Soil 57,600 World average [13]

In the present work, our aim was to measure radon exhalation rate from the most common building materials. Solid state nuclear track detectors (SSNTD) (CR-39) have been used to determine radon exhalation rate from different building materials collected from Manisa and Izmir provinces of Turkey.
The lowest value of radon exhalation rate was 87 ± 9 mBq m−2 h−1 in a sample of granite and the highest value of radon exhalation rate was 1204 ± 35 mBq m−2 h−1 in a sample of ashlar.
As may be seen, the maximum average radon exhalation rate was observed in the ashlar samples (599 ± 25 mBq m−2 h−1) and the minimum was observed in the ceramic tile samples (309 ± 18 mBq m−2 h−1).

The radon exhalations in these samples were well below the world average value of 57 600 mBq m−2 h−1. Hence, it is concluded that these materials may be used for construction purposes, as they do not pose any health hazards due to low exhalation of radon.
